column1: Obama welcomes Netanyahu
The relationship between Obama and Netanyahu is not exactly friendly.
The two wanted to discuss the implementation of the international agreement and Tehran's destabilizing actions in the Middle East.
The meeting will also focus on the conflict with the Palestinians and the two-state solution being discussed.
Relations between Obama and Netanyahu have been strained for years.
Washington criticizes Israel's continued settlement construction and accuses Netanyahu of a lack of will in the peace process.
The Obama-touted deal on Iran's nuclear program has further worsened the relationship between the two.
In March, Netanyahu gave a controversial speech to the US Congress at the invitation of Republicans, which was seen in part as an affront to Obama.
The speech had not been arranged with Obama, who had declined a meeting with reference to the upcoming election in Israel at the time.
In emergency call, professor confesses to shooting his girlfriend
In an emergency call, Professor Shannon Lamb told police in a slightly shaky voice that he had shot his girlfriend and that officers had to come to his house.
Lamb was keen to stress that his "sweet dog" was still alive and probably upset, and said the dead woman's family contacts could be found on her phone.

Inside the house, officers found Amy Prentiss's body and a handwritten note scrawled on a white pad: "I'm so sorry, I wanted I could undo it, I loved Amy and she's the only woman who ever loved me." This was written in the letter, according to authorities, and it was signed by Lamb.

There was no indication that Lamb, who taught two online courses for Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, had traveled 300 miles to the school grounds where he shot and killed a popular history professor, Ethan Schmidt, at the door of his office, according to police.
Delta State University Police Chief Lynn Buford said university employees heard the shooting at 10: 18 a.m.
He said Lamb made the fatal emergency call sometime after that.
By the end of the day, there was another death: Lamb took his own life when police surrounded him.
A day after the university shooting that forced students and faculty to hide behind closed doors, authorities are still trying to figure out what motivated Lamb.

The details released by investigators at both ends of the state, as well as what students and staff members who knew him testified, helped paint a picture of a talented but possibly difficult teacher.
Students said they were looking forward to his classes.
Police in Gautier, where Prentiss died, said he had no history of violence or criminal history.
Schmidt himself had mentioned Lamb in a book he had written, in which he mentioned the "wonderful people" with whom he shared his academic life.
Both taught in the Department of Social Sciences and History, which has 17 faculty members, and many students attended courses from both.
At the same time, there were some tendencies towards problematic behaviour.
One student, Brandon Beavers, who praised Lamb, said he also seemed a little excited and nervous "as if there was something wrong with him."
Another student, Mikel Sykes, said Lamb told him he was dealing with stress at the end of the 2014-15 academic year.
Lamb had previously asked Delta State University for a leave of absence for health reasons, saying he had some kind of health problem.
This year, he taught only two online courses.
Recent changes in the university's employment policy meant that the doctorate Lamb had worked so hard for would not guarantee him an automatic path to an assistant professor position.
University President William LaForge said he was unaware of any conflict between Lamb and Schmidt, but "of course there was something in Mr. Lamb's mind."
These are questions Lamb can no longer answer.
After fleeing the campus, police later found Lamb's trail as he drove back into Mississippi from Arkansas.

Before he could be arrested, Lamb killed himself with a .38-caliber pistol in the backyard of a home about a mile south of his childhood home on the outskirts of Greenville, Mississippi, Washington County Coroner Methel Johnson said.
His car was still in the driveway.
It was not immediately clear why Lamb went to the house, but Johnson said she believes he knew the people who lived there.
Lamb grew up in the area.
Lamb began working at the university, which has 3,500 students in a city of about 12,000 people, in 2009 and taught geography and pedagogy.
He received his doctorate in education in the spring.
One of Lamb's longtime friends described him as intelligent, charismatic and funny.
Carla Hairston said she was 15 and Lamb was 20 when they met through mutual friends.
She and her friends were in high school, and he was the cool older guy who tried to teach her to play the guitar for a few years.
He was the crush of women back then.
All the girls melted away when he was there, "said Hairston, now 40 and a resident of the Jackson suburb of Brandon.
Lamb and Prentiss were obviously together for some time.
In the distress call, Lamb said "I killed my wife," but there was no certificate of marriage.
They had a dog named Lightning who lived with them in the brick house adjacent to a Bayou in Gautier.
Police said the dog was fine.
Prentiss' ex-husband, Shawn O'Steen, said they divorced 15 years ago but had remained friends and had a daughter who was now 19.
She was absolutely devastated, O'Steen said of his daughter.
She and her mother were absolutely best friends.
O'Steen said he never met Lamb, but through his daughter Abigail he heard that Lamb was interested in music and played blues.
Lamb met Prentiss when he and Abigail both performed at a summer fair three years ago.
Later they played the odd gig together.
O'Steen said his daughter writes and sings her own music.
Prentiss was a nurse who worked for various companies online.

Mike Shaffer, a bartender and sometimes entertainment coordinator at The Julep Room, a dimly lit bar near Gautier, said he last saw Lamb and Prentiss Night on the night of September 5 after Lamb finished playing his guitar and harmonica in front of a sparse crowd.
There was no sign that anything was wrong.
Just a happy couple, he said.
We were tidying up and joking with each other.
I mean, they both had a good sense of humour.
Schmidt, the dead professor, led the freshman seminar program and specialized in Native American and colonial history, said Don Allan Mitchell, an English professor at the school.
He was married with three young children.
He studied at Emporia State University in Kansas and was president of his fraternity and student committee.
About 900 people, including faculty, staff, students and members of the community, attended a candlelight memorial service on the Delta State campus in Cleveland on Tuesday night.
Schmidt's wife Liz and brother Jeff Schmidt also attended the vigil, while the university choir sang "Bright Morning Star" and "Amazing Grace."
Classes will resume on Wednesday.
We're trying to get our students to return, LaForge said.
The crisis is over.
This is a day of healing.
Amy and Rogelio Solis reported from Cleveland, Mississippi.
Associated Press writers Emily Wagster Pettus in Greenville, Mississippi, and Rebecca Santana in New Orleans contributed to this report.

This story has been corrected to reflect that police now say Lamb made the distress call after he shot Schmidt, and that Lamb referred to Prentiss as his wife in his distress call, but there is no indication that the two ever married.
Toys R Us plans to hire fewer workers for the holiday season

Toys R Us says it won't hire as many Christmas season employees as it did last year, but the toy and baby products retailer says it will give current employees and seasonal workers a chance to work more hours.
The company said it plans to hire 40,000 people in stores and distribution centers across the country, up from 45,000 in the 2014 holiday season.
Most jobs will be part-time.
The company said it will begin job interviews this month and the number of employees will increase from October to December.

With the holidays themselves still months away, the holiday shopping season is approaching, and companies are preparing to hire temporary workers to equip stores with employees to sell, ship and deliver products.
Michael J. Fox jokes about his' date 'with Princess Diana
The premiere of "Back to the Future" was a big moment for Michael J. Fox.
It was also remarkable for personal reasons.

We were sitting in the theater waiting for the royals, and I realize that the seat next to me is empty, and I'm beginning to realize that Princess Diana will be sitting next to me, he said in a trailer for an upcoming documentary, "Back in Time."
The film begins, and it occurs to me that I'm a simulated yawn and an arm's length away from being on a date with the Princess of Wales.
Back in Time, a documentary about "Back to the Future," features interviews with Fox, Lea Thompson and Christopher Lloyd, as well as director Robert Zemeckis and producer Steven Spielberg.
Back for the Future premiered 30 years ago.
For me, Spielberg said, "it's unquestionably the greatest time-travel movie ever made."
Back in Time will be available on VOD, DVD and in select theaters in October.
UN chief says there is no military solution in Syria

Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon says his response to Russia's increased military support for Syria is that "there is no military solution" to the nearly five-year conflict, and more weapons will only exacerbate violence and misery for millions of people.
The UN chief reiterates his call for all parties, including the divided UN Security Council, to unite and support inclusive negotiations to find a political solution.

Ban told a news conference on Wednesday that he plans to meet the foreign ministers of the five permanent member nations of the council - the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France - on the sidelines of the General Assembly ministerial meeting later this month to discuss the situation in Syria.
He deplored that divisions within the Council and within the Syrian people and regional powers "make this situation intractable."
Ban called on the five permanent members to show the same solidarity and unity in dealing with the crisis in Syria that they have shown in reaching a nuclear deal with Iran.
8 poll showing that Donald Trump is serious.
Some have tried to brand it a flop.
Others have dismissed it as a joke.
And some are waiting for a collapse.
But no matter how some Republicans try to drag Donald Trump down from the top of the polls, it hasn't (yet) worked.

Ten of the last 11 national polls have shown Donald Trump leading by double digits, and some are beginning to seriously wonder what it means for the real estate mogul's chances of winning the nomination.
Of course, it is too early in the parliamentary term.
No one is suggesting that Trump is likely to win the Republican nomination.
Experts point out that at this time in 2011, Rick Perry's lead was surrendered to the rising Herman Cain, neither of whom won a single state in the nominating process.
And there are many reasons why he would struggle in a General Election.

But outsider groups like Jeb Bush's Super PAC and the conservative business group Club for Growth are now recognizing Trump's staying power and are beginning to pour their dollars into trying to topple him.
Here are some recent poll numbers that suggest the real estate mogul is not just a passing phase:
Trump's approval ratings have turned 180 degrees.
Shortly before Donald Trump announced his candidacy in mid-June, a Monmouth University poll showed that only two in 10 Republicans viewed the real estate mogul favorably.
By mid-July, it was 40 percent.
At the start of August, it was 52 per cent.
Now, six in 10 Republicans have a favorable view of Donald Trump.
About three in 10 say they have a negative opinion.
And those numbers hold up in early states.
A Quinnipiac poll in Iowa last week found that 60 percent of Republicans have a favorable opinion of Trump.
Two-thirds of GOP voters would be happy with Trump as the nominee.
In a CNN / ORC poll last week, 67 percent of Republicans said they would be either "thrilled" or "satisfied" if Trump were nominated.
Only two in 10 say they would be "upset" if he were the nominee.
Only Ben Carson generates roughly the same enthusiasm as Trump (43 percent say they are "thrilled" vs. 40 percent who say the same about Trump).
The next in terms of enthusiasm?
Marco Rubio with just 21 percent.
On the other hand, 47 percent of Republican voters say they would be "dissatisfied" or "angry" if Jeb Bush, the establishment favorite, became the nominee.
A majority of Republicans don't see Trump's temperament as a problem.

While Donald Trump is widely criticized for his bombastic and insulting statements, 52 percent of Republican-leaning Irish voters believe the real estate mogul has the right temperament for a president, ABC News / Washington Post reported Monday.
The same number is true in the nation's first primary state, Iowa, where the same 52 percent of Republicans think he has the personality for a commander in chief, according to Quinnipiac last week.
Still, 44 percent think he doesn't have the personality to effectively run for office, and nearly six in 10 independents say his temperament doesn't fit into the White House, according to ABC / Post.
Republican voters are getting used to the idea.
When they put on their scholar hats, Republican voters think Trump is real.
When asked who is most likely to win the GOP nomination, four in 10 say Trump is the best bet, according to a CNN / ORC poll released last week.
That's a shift from when four in 10 put their money on Jeb Bush at the end of July.
Full disclosure: GOP voters haven't had the clearest crystal ball in the past.
At this point in the last cycle, four in 10 Republicans thought Rick Perry would win the nomination, compared to just 28% for eventual nominee Mitt Romney.
Still, it turns out that a large number of GOP voters see Trump's campaign as plausible.
Even as Republicans rallied around another candidate, Trump still beats almost everyone.
Some experts point out that the fragmented field is likely contributing to Trump's lead, while anti-Trump support is diffuse among more than a dozen other candidates.
But a Monmouth University poll in early September shows that in a hypothetical head-to-head race between Trump and most other Republican candidates, Trump is reaping majority support.
He is 13 points ahead of Carly Fiorina, 14 points ahead of Marco Rubio, 15 points ahead of Walker, 19 points ahead of Jeb Bush and 33 points ahead of Rand Paul, John Kasich and Chris Christie.
It's a head-to-head race with Ted Cruz.
The only candidate who beats him?
Ben Carson would overtake the businessman by 19 points in a hypothetical head-to-head race.
A slim majority of Donald Trump supporters say they have made up their minds.
A new CBS / NYT poll released Tuesday shows that just over half of voters who support Trump say they have cast their ballots.
Of course, much can be done to change that, and no one can really say never to change their mind.
Forty-six percent said they left the door open to switching to other candidates.
Still, Trump's strongest competitor right now is the other outsider, neurosurgeon Ben Carson, but voters who say they've made up their minds are twice as likely to vote for Trump.
Six in 10 Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
Since Donald Trump called immigrants from Mexico "rapists" in his campaign speech two months ago, immigration has been the lynchpin of the 2016 public discourse.
Some worry that Trump's bombastic language will keep crucial Hispanic Americans away from the Republican Party and damage redistricting efforts.
But according to Monday's new ABC / Post poll, six in 10 Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
So as long as immigration remains in the spotlight, it seems Donald Trump will.
Frustration with the government is climbing to new highs.
Donald Trump and Ben Carson now account for about half the support of Republican voters, largely because of their outsider status.
Six in 10 Republicans in the new ABC / Post Monday poll say they'd rather have a political outsider than someone with government experience.
And they're angry with Washington, too.

A Des Moines Register / Bloomberg poll in Iowa two weeks ago showed that three in four Iowa Republicans are frustrated with congressional Republicans, with 54 percent "dissatisfied" and 21 percent "angry."

Champions League: Bayern dream start thanks to Muller and Götze
Double goalscorer in Piraeus: Bayern star Thomas Muller just has a run.
A lucky goal from Thomas Muller paved the way for Bayern to a deserved 3-0 win at Olympiakos Piraeus - then it was on.
A confident start to the Champions League season.
World champions Thomas Müller and Mario Götze have given Bayern a dream start to their "Mission Milan" in the cauldron of Piraeus.

Coach Pep Guardiola's team won their opening game in the Champions League at Greek record-holder Olympiakos in a hot atmosphere thanks to Müller's double (52. / 90. + 2) and Götzes goal (89.) earned 3: 0 (0: 0).
The twelfth success in a row is supposed to be the first step towards the final on May 28, 2016 in Italy, where Guardiola finally wants to bring the trophy to Munich at the third attempt.
Muller, on his 28th goal for Bayern in the Champions League, was assisted by Olympiakos goalkeeper Roberto, who let a shot from the edge of the area pass him.
We will not underestimate them, Bayern captain Philipp Lahm had promised before the match at the Karaiskakis Stadium in front of 31,688 hot-blooded fans - and Munich kept their word.
They put on a concentrated and committed performance without shining.
Piraeus had won its last six home games in the Premier League, including against big-name clubs such as Manchester United, Atlético Madrid and Juventus.
Borussia Dortmund (1-3) also stumbled here in 2011.
But Bayern, unbeaten in seven European Cup matches with Greek teams, did not want to be the next victim.
They were courageous, but often too unimaginative in their offensive efforts.
The attacks were too often started by shifting play to left winger Douglas Costa, who rarely got through against former Brunswick man Omar Elabdellaoui.
Muller had more luck from the right when his right-footed half-volley hit the top left corner of the goal.
The world champions went 2-0 up in the 67th minute.
Robert Lewandowski had the best chances in the first half.
First, when Olympiakos striker Ideye Brown knocked the Pole's header off the line (26th).
Then a direct clearance that goalkeeper Roberto parried with his knee (35th).
Although the Bavarians put up their usual dominant game, Piraeus was able to put pinpricks.
Goalkeeper Manuel Neuer could be relied upon, though.
Like when he deflected a shot from Ideye over the crossbar (56th).
Before Neuer, Guardiola had a four-man defence with David Alaba in the centre alongside Jerome Boateng, who did well.
Mario Götze, back in the squad after muscular problems, initially sat out.
The World Cup hero only gave the green light after the final training session, sports director Matthias Sammer told Sky: "If you want to make something else out of it, that's evil."
Even at the first change, Guardiola decided against him when he brought on Kingsley Coman for the injured Lewandowski (59th).
Götze came on late for Arturo Vidal (76th) and made it all clear 13 minutes later, with Müller adding a penalty.
There had been riots in the stadium before the game.

After a smaller group of partially masked Bayern fans in their spectator block had apparently provoked the supporters of host Piraeus with words and gestures, the security forces intervened and proceeded with batons against the Munich supporters.
At least one Bayern fan was transported from the stadium injured.
People who smoke have a higher risk of losing teeth
Smoking causes damage not only to the lungs but also to the teeth, a long-term study in Potsdam suggests.
The good news is that if you give up, the risk drops quickly.
Smokers have a significantly increased risk of losing their teeth early.
This is the conclusion of a long-term study by an international team of researchers, including several employees of the German Institute of Human Nutrition (DIfE) in Potsdam.
Compared to non-smokers, smokers were 2.5 to 3.6 times more likely to lose their teeth prematurely.
The scientists had observed more than 23,300 participants.
The main causes of tooth loss are tooth decay and inflammation of the gums, stresses the DIfE.
Smoking is a risk factor for this periodontitis, the authors stress.
The association between smoking and tooth loss is therefore due to more frequent gum inflammation in smokers.
It is not clear to what extent smoking also increases the risk of tooth decay.
However, people who quit smoking could reduce their risk within a short period of time, the researchers write in the Journal of Dental Research.
However, it could take more than ten years for the risk to return to the level of non-smokers, said lead author Thomas Dietrich of the University of Birmingham in England.
Study leader Heiner Boeing of the DIfE explained that people need to be persuaded to become non-smokers: "Smoking shortens life spans."
Not smoking is good for the lungs and blood vessels and, according to our findings, also leads to good dental health into old age.
In Germany, more than 20 percent of the population aged 65 to 74 is affected by toothlessness, according to the DIfE.
Previous research has suggested that smoking increases the risk of early tooth loss.
The new long-term study supports the findings.
Archaeologists find remains from Late Antiquity on the banks of the Rhine in Cologne
Once again, archaeological finds have been made on the right bank of the Rhine in Cologne.

Archaeologists from the Roman-Germanic Museum have excavated skeletons and remains of historic buildings near the construction site for the new Rhine boulevard, museum director Marcus Trier said on Tuesday.
Since the beginning of the construction work on the Rhine, historians have been searching for so-called ground monuments.
In all construction projects in the Cologne district, the museum is always consulted as a specialist office for the preservation of archaeological monuments.
In the third construction phase of the Rhine boulevard, the archaeologists found what they were looking for.
From text documents it was already known that there was a fortress on the site in the 4th century and a church in the 8th century, Trier explained.
In addition to the remains of the fortress and the church tower, a cemetery with around 350 graves was discovered, which probably belonged to the church.
Young woman hit by freight train
Federal police are appealing for the public's help after a young woman died in an accident at a train station in Geilenkirchen-Lindern.

Early on Wednesday morning at around 1.40am, the woman, coming from the direction of the station building, crossed the tracks at the end of the platform and was hit by a freight train coming from the direction of Mönchengladbach.
According to federal police, she sustained serious injuries when the train hit her.
She was treated at the scene and taken to hospital by paramedics.
Investigating officers have no information about the reason for the young woman crossing the tracks at night.
The incident may have been witnessed by witnesses or residents may have heard audible noises.
Residents or passers-by of Linderner Bahn, Ziegelbäckerweg, Thomashofstraße and Leiffarther Straße (L364) are eligible.
Information about the cause of the accident can be given by calling the Federal Police's 24-hour free hotline on 0800 / 6888000 or any other police station.
EU Commission proposes new court in dispute over TTIP
In order to defuse the dispute over the planned transatlantic free trade agreement TTIP, the EU Commission has proposed a comprehensive reform of the current arbitration system.

The controversial private arbitration mechanisms for disputes between corporations and states are to be replaced by a more transparent system, which in its functioning corresponds to much more traditional courts.
We want to put in place a system that citizens trust, said Commissioner Cecilia Malmström at the launch.
The Swede intends to introduce the proposal as a European negotiating position in the free trade talks with the USA.
The German government announced support.
TTIP is intended to create the largest free trade area in the world with 800 million people.
Specifically, the plans to reform the current arbitration procedures foresee that the EU states and the US jointly select independent judges for a new Investment Court.
They should come equally from the EU, the USA and third countries.
For the first time, a second instance is also envisaged.
It would make it possible to appeal judgments.
Up to now, the parties to the proceedings have agreed among themselves on arbitrators, but there has been no possibility of appealing against their verdicts.
In the discussion of the past few months, it became clear that citizens did not trust the old ISDS system in terms of fairness and justice, commented Malmström.
In the long term, it says it wants to work towards an International Investment Tribunal.
There, for example, disputes between Chinese companies and EU countries could be resolved.
Investor-state arbitration (ISDS), which is mainly demanded by large corporations, is considered one of the main reasons for the great opposition in Europe to TTIP.

Traditional arbitration courts have been criticized by opponents as a kind of parallel justice through which companies can seek damages at the expense of taxpayers, overturn national laws, or enforce a lowering of consumer and environmental standards.
In initial statements, anti-TTIP organisations such as Campact described the proposals of the EU Commission as insufficient.
The main criticism was that they should not apply to the already negotiated free trade agreement with Canada (Ceta).
The German State Secretary for Economic Affairs Matthias Machnig (SPD), on the other hand, described the plans as great progress.
The Commission takes into account key points in the reform, which Federal Minister of Economics Sigmar Gabriel worked out with other EU trade ministers in the spring.
The old system of private arbitration is off the table.
The French Government also welcomed Malmström's plans.
BusinessEurope, the European business association, warned that too many new rules would restrict the business community's ability to sue.
Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular could be put at a disadvantage, it said.
It remained unclear on Wednesday when talks on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) free trade agreement could be concluded.
Negotiations have been ongoing since mid-2013.
However, the issue of investor protection has not yet been discussed with the US.
Originally, a framework for the agreement was supposed to be in place by the end of this year.
This date is no longer valid.
Delicate Folk by Sufjan Stevens in Hamburg
Eleven years ago Sufjan Stevens was sitting on stage at the Prime Club in Cologne (today: Luxor).
Next to him is a flip chart on which the shy folk singer has drawn the picturesque US state of Michigan with felt-tip pen.
The entire audience, about 40 people, is almost moved by Steven's lecture.
He tells the story of his meticulously and delicately arranged songs by means of various locations, which he repeatedly draws on the map.
Where they were made and what it looks like there, in his homeland.
Since then, Stevens has proved to be a wonderfully creative lunatic.

With the third album "Greetings from Michigan: The Great Lake State," released in 2003, cleverly composed songs appear, which nestle harmoniously very close to American folk of the late sixties, but can drift into great opulence at any time.
Rumor has it that "Michigan" is the first part of a daring series: each of the 50 US states should be sung in a row.
But already in 2004 and near the Rhine "Seven Swans" was released and positively breaks certain expectations.
Stevens makes a reduced appearance here.
Live, guitar and banjo are enough for him.
A year later, the New York-based musician returns to the series.
Illinois ("Sufjan Stevens Invites You To: Come on Feel The Illinoise") is a widely acclaimed masterpiece released in 2005.
Exuberant in ideas and stylistic finesse.
The album enters the American Billboard charts and is not missing from any annual best-seller list of the influential music media.
After extremely productive experiments, Stevens then makes extensive use of electronic set pieces on "The Age of Adz" (2010).
This sixth proper studio album is still broadly orchestrated, but carried by programmed sequences or beats, and plays with all sorts of effects and reverberations.
Long since emerged from the smaller clubs, the stage shows here become a colourful spectacle of neon headbands and large fluorescent stage decoration.
Sufjan Stevens is currently touring Germany as part of a five-piece band.
In the dark hamburger More!
Theater, he mainly presents "Carrie & Lowell," which has been available since March.
Although there are now almost 2000 guests sitting spellbound in their chairs, Stevens, who has matured considerably, returns to intimacy and folk.
Without saying a word to the audience, the group of excellent musicians play their way through the broadly enriched album.
One hears from the audience that the lecture is "more opulent" and that you can "basically throw away the record."
Only for an encore Stevens thanks modestly, plays acoustically few older songs and finally bows to thunderous applause.
Jeremy Corbyn's debut at Prime Minister's Questions
Since his election, Mr Corbyn's debut at Prime Minister's Questions has been eagerly awaited
New Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is to make his debut at Prime Minister's Questions, taking on David Cameron for the first time.
Mr Corbyn will stand up to take the first of his six questions shortly after midday, with his performance likely to be scrutinised by the media and Labour MPs up close.
He called for "less theatre and more facts" at the weekly event.
He also said he could skip some meetings to leave them to colleagues.
The encounter will be the first parliamentary test of Mr Corbyn's leadership as it comes after his appointment to the shadow cabinet and after his speech to the TUC annual conference on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, the Labour leader's decision to remain silent during the singing of the national anthem at a commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain on Tuesday has provoked criticism from a number of Tory MPs and is at the centre of several front-page stories in newspapers.
Mr Corbyn's decision not to sing the national anthem has attracted attention
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said he had 'stood in respectful silence' and recognised the 'heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain'.

But a member of Mr Corbyn's shadow cabinet, Owen Smith, told the BBC Two Newsnight programme that he had advised the Labour leader to sing the national anthem "regardless" of his belief that the monarchy should be abolished.

Nearly a dozen shadow ministers have refused to serve on Mr Corbyn's top team, citing differences on the economy, defence and foreign policy, while less than a sixth of the parliamentary party originally backed him as leader.
The BBC's political correspondent Robin Brant says political differences are also "piling up" within Labour, following Mr Corbyn's comments on the European Union and limits on profits.
Mr Corbyn told the TUC conference that Labour was tabling amendments to remove the whole idea of a cap altogether.
Hours later Mr Smith, the shadow work and pensions secretary, said the party was "very clear" it was only opposed to government plans to cut the cap from £26,000 to £23,000.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron across the Dispatch Box in Parliament in the past decade since he became Tory leader.
The Labour leader, who has promised a different approach to politics, says he has "crowd-sourced" ideas for questions to Mr Cameron and has received more than 30,000 suggestions.

The Islington North MP has said Prime Minister's Questions is too confrontational, and that he will refrain from both "posturing" and barb-fighting and instead focus on serious issues such as poverty, inequality and the challenges facing young people.
Mr Corbyn has said that Angela Eagle, the shadow business secretary, will replace him if he does not attend - for example, when Mr Cameron is abroad.
He has also floated the idea of other colleagues speaking occasionally, and that he has approached John Bercow, the Speaker of the House of Commons, to discuss the issue.

When he became leader in 2005, Mr Cameron said he wanted to move away from "Punch and Judy" style politics, often associated with Prime Minister's Questions, but admitted a few years later that he had failed.

First broadcast on television in 1990, Prime Minister's Question Time was seen as the most important barometer of a leader's judgment and leadership in the House of Commons and his standing among his parliamentary colleagues, although critics have argued that it has become a caricature and needs far-reaching reform.

As Aldi prepares to open two distribution centres and the first 120 stores in South Australia and Western Australia early next year, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with local food suppliers and building the IGA brand through mainstream marketing and marketing via social media, as well as events such as the Adelaide show.

IGA retailers and suppliers are jumping on board, with brands such as Dunsborough-based ice cream maker Simmo handing out samples in IGA stores and shopkeepers selling discounted tickets for the South Australian Football League to loyal customers.

The stakes are high as South Australia and Western Australia account for almost 30 per cent of Metcash's IGA stores and generate higher profit margins than Metcash's IGA network in the eastern states.

Shoppers in South Australia and Western Australia are notoriously provincial and IGA retailers have a much stronger market share than in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in South Australia and 24 per cent in Western Australia compared to around 14 per cent in the eastern states.

However, analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe Aldi will snatch around five per cent of the grocery market in those two states 12 months after opening its first stores, taking sales away from all existing players but mainly independent retailers.

This forecast is based on the assumption that Aldi will open 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA next year, generating sales of $500 million and $600 million in each market.
The loss in the food and grocery business and volumes on Metcash's high fixed cost basis could cost Metcash about $13 million in earnings before interest and tax, Mr Kierath said.
At the same time, Metcash is losing market share in the eastern states, mainly to Aldi and Coles, although a recent Roy Morgan survey found that IGA shoppers are the most loyal.

A rate hike is coming, and the bull market will falter, bond yields will rise, and the economy will slide into recession.
We know that.
What we don't know is how long it will take and how long it will last.
In particular, history offers little guidance for the economy.
A recession came within 11 months of the first rate hike and lasted 86 months.
The Federal Reserve's aggressiveness in raising interest rates is often, if not always, a factor in how the economy and financial assets respond.
That is why US central bank officials have emphasized so strongly that investors should focus not on when it starts raising interest rates, but rather on the period of time needed for normalization.
In fact, several variables play a role.
In the end, however, market participants may find that all the excitement about a rate hike may have been exaggerated.

The Fed's first hike since the global financial crisis will inevitably be interpreted by some as signaling the end of the era of cheap money, "" Julian Jessop, chief economist at Capital Economics, said in a note to clients.
By contrast, we do not expect the gradual return of US interest rates to normal levels, but still too low to cause the seismic shock that many seem to fear.
This does not mean, however, that there will be no impact.
Here's a look at how some sectors of the economy might react, based on historical trends:
As the market has seen over the past month, anticipating rate hikes can make things volatile for a while.
Once the increase arrives, the impact is not so dramatic.

There seems to be a tendency for asset yields to stall 12 to 24 months after the first hike, perhaps reflecting the delay in monetary policy, Deutsche Bank analysts said in a recent study of what happens after Fed rate hikes.

More specifically, over the past 35 years, the market has mostly been on an upward trajectory - about 14% - toward a rate hike, fairly flat in the 250 days thereafter (average gain of 2.6%), then back to normal after 500 days, with an average return over the past six cycles of 14.4%, according to a recent analysis published by Bob Doll, chief investment strategist at Nuveen Asset Management at Barron's.
Deutsche Bank said the impact on stocks tends to occur later in the cycle and the yield starts to decline.
Recessions are a fact of economic life, but rate hikes often encourage them.
In the current case, the Fed is facing some conditions that did not exist before and that could accelerate a recession.
Most remarkably, gross domestic product will be close to its lowest point when the Fed raises interest rates.
According to Deutsche Bank, of the 118 rate hikes since 1950, nominal GDP has been below 4.5% only twice.
Although the second quarter of 2015 was 3.6 percent, few expect that to continue, and expect only 1.5 percent in the third quarter, according to the Atlanta Fed.
Raising interest rates in such a fragile economic backdrop could be risky, raising the question "whether this time is different," Deutsche Bank said.
Market participants have been bracing for a Fed rate hike all year, and all eyes were on this week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which ends Thursday.
While many strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve a hike this session, futures trading gives only a 25 percent chance.

In our study, all increase cycles from 1950 to the present have occurred in a super-cycle with increasing momentum in GDP, dwarfing pre-recession peaks very quickly after the recovery began, the report said.
By contrast, this is a distinctly slow recovery from what was the worst recession in recorded history.
The current cycle is by far the longest the Fed has waited since the end of the last recession; the record was 35 months, and that's 74 months so far.
Fixed income has also been volatile, as the market anticipates a rate hike, and the pattern is quite similar to the capital market.
The main difference is that the effect on bonds is faster than on equities when they change their strategic course.
For bonds, yields seem to change direction as soon as the first rise / fall in the cycle occurs.
At the end of the increase cycle, bond yields fall immediately, Deutsche Bank said.

Scientists have bred worms with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves.
The tiny nematodes change direction the moment they are irradiated with sound impulses that are too high frequencies for human hearing to be heard.
The impulses work by switching on motor neuron cells that are genetically modified to carry the membrane channels that respond to ultrasound waves.
More on this topic: Researchers read and write brain activity with light
The researchers said the worms showed the power of a new technique, called sonogenetics, in which ultrasound can be used to activate a range of brain, heart and muscle cells outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep brain stimulation, an invasive procedure that sends electrical impulses into people's brains to treat symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
Roundworms don't usually respond to ultrasound, but Chalasani found that they did when surrounded by a fluid with microscopic air bubbles.
The bubbles, he found, amplify the ultrasound waves that then penetrate the worms.
The amplified ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels found in the membranes of some of the worm cells.
The sound waves cause these ion channels to open and activate the cells to which they are assigned, according to a report in Nature Communications.
To create ultrasound-guided nematodes, Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carry TRP-4 ion channels.
When he applies ultrasound to the modified creatures, the sound waves are amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted to the worms, where they turn on the modified motor neurons.
The method has some similarities to Optogenetics, a ground-breaking tool that allows scientists to turn neurons on and off with pulses of light.
But Chalasani said Sonogenetics could have some advantages over this technique.

Unlike light, which must be sent down an optical fiber to the desired location in the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissues unhindered and can thus be sent to the brain from the top of the skull.

We believe that with gene therapy and a therapeutic virus it is possible to make the targeted human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments, Chalasani said.
Other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells, he added.

For slightly overweight diabetics, weight loss surgery can be helpful.
The benefits of weight loss surgery for slightly overweight people with type 2 diabetes can last at least five years, according to a new study.
It is too early to say whether slightly overweight people with diabetes live longer after weight loss surgery than those who receive non-surgical treatments.
The mortality data take a long time to show anything, said Dr. Robin Blackstone, a weight-loss surgery expert who wrote an editorial on the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight loss surgeries, or obesity surgery, use various methods to reduce the size of the stomach.
They reduce hunger and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Over the years, obesity surgery to treat type 2 diabetes has proven effective, but most studies have been conducted in people who are morbidly obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a measure of weight in terms of height, is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9.
A BMI of 25 or more indicates someone is overweight, and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI here: 1.usa.gov / 1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, the researchers from Taiwan's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data collected in a study since 2007, comparing two types of obesity surgery - gastric bypass and gastric tube formation - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were slightly overweight.
The average BMI among those who underwent the surgery dropped from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year in this study.
Meanwhile, BMI remained roughly the same for those who received non-surgical diabetes treatments.
Among those who underwent surgery, 36% had diabetes completely resolved and 28% partially.
In the medically treated group, in comparison, diabetes resolved completely in only one percent and partially in only about two percent.
In addition, the results for controls of blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol were "generally better in the 'surgical' group," the authors found.
The researchers also monitored patient blood levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects blood sugar levels over time.
Hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent, the researchers write.
After surgery, the average hemoglobin A1c level dropped from about 9 percent to about 6 percent.
In the medical therapy group, however, it remained stable at about 8 percent.
But this better "glycemic control" - reflected in improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce mortality in five years, according to lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and his colleagues.
The research team also compared average outcomes for the two types of surgery.

In the fifth year, the bypass surgery group lost more weight (18.7 vs. 14.2 kg) compared to the gastric rectomy group, achieved greater decreases in BMI (7.4 vs. 5.1) and hemoglobin A1c (3.1% vs. 2.1%), and were more likely to completely overcome diabetes (46.9% vs. 16.7%).

While the new study shows no survival benefit from surgery after five years, there is evidence from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery leads to a longer life, says Blackstone of the University of Arizona, College of Medicine Phoenix.
In the Swedish study, obese people who underwent obesity surgery were about 29 percent less likely to die over the course of 15 years, compared to a group who tried more conventional methods.
Although the new study showed no benefit for survival among surgery patients, Blackstone said it was reassuring for people with a BMI below 35 who are interested in the procedure.
That's the critical point of this study because it says this surgery is lower in this lower BMI group, with no increased risk of death or kidney disease, she said.
Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously once the patient's BMI is between 27 and 30.
I think we're waiting too long to get people to take this seriously, she said.
I think once they've accumulated these genetic changes that have tied their bodies to obesity and diabetes, it's really hard to reverse. '

Hand sanitizers contain anywhere between 45 and 95 percent alcohol.
Even a few splashes can lead to alcohol poisoning, especially in young children.

JVA Berlin-Tegel: Five square metres of cells are inhumane
The Federal Constitutional Court has ruled in favour of an ex-prisoner of the Tegel penitentiary, who was housed for months in a cell that was too small.
Because of the violation of their human dignity, prisoners are in principle entitled to financial compensation if they are housed in cells that are too small.
This was decided by the Federal Constitutional Court in a decision published on Wednesday.
According to the judges, the persons concerned can hope for money even if they were locked up in the too narrow rooms for only a few days (file no.: 1 BvR 1127 / 14).

Thus, an ex-prisoner was successful with his constitutional complaint in Karlsruhe: Between June and November 2009, he was housed in a solitary cell with about five square meters of floor space in the Berlin-Tegel penitentiary; the toilet was not spatially separated.
The man, who according to his lawyer is now at large, was then moved to a larger cell.
His legal action against the state of Berlin for the undignified conditions of his imprisonment failed.
But the constitutional judges overturned the verdict of the Berlin Court of Appeal and sent the case back there for re-examination.
They see the man's human dignity violated.
Court of Appeal now decides on amount of compensation
Even if, for legal reasons, only a few days of detention from the period in question were decisive for the compensation, there was a claim for compensation, it was said.
Failure to do so would "lead to a deterioration of the legal protection of the individual."
The Court of Appeal must now clarify the amount of compensation.
Constitutional judges have often strengthened the rights of prisoners in the past.
As recently as April, they awarded damages to an inmate for being locked up naked in a cell.
According to a 2011 decision, the multiple occupancy of a cell without a separate toilet is also inhumane.
Furthermore, Karlsruhe also confirmed on Wednesday the Berlin Constitutional Court, which had certified an inhumane accommodation for a prisoner in a parallel case in November 2009.
The plaintiff at that time was accommodated daily for three months between 15 and 21 hours in a cell of the same type as in the Karlsruhe case.
Berlin's prisons have also hit the headlines in recent weeks for a lack of staff.
Prisoners are therefore repeatedly locked up for 23 hours, the aggressiveness increases, even brawls are said to have taken place because of the tense situation.
According to the judicial press office, 21 vacancies in Tegel are unfilled due to a lack of young talent, with 19 to be eliminated in 2016.

What lies ahead for Germany?

According to forecasts by the Federal Ministry of the Interior, around 800,000 asylum seekers will come to Germany this year. According to Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel (SPD), Germany is even in a position to take in one million refugees.
Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU) has shown determination in the face of the unusual challenge: "I say again and again: we can do it, and we can do it."
The following overview provides an overview of what is to come for Germany.

According to different forecasts, between 350,000 (estimate by the Federal Ministry of Construction) and 400,000 (estimate by the Pestel Institute) apartments will be needed annually - for the next five years.
This is almost twice as much as is currently being built (250,000 homes).

However, the shortage of housing is particularly dramatic in the case of affordable rental properties: 60,000 to 80,000 social housing units fall out of the fixed rent system every year, and refugees will also apply for these particularly affordable apartments.
Federal Building Minister Barbara Hendricks (SPD) therefore wants to double the funding, from currently 518 million to one billion euros.

From the point of view of the Pestel Institute, this is far too little: 80,000 social housing units a year would have to be built and for this the federal government would have to invest a subsidy of 6.4 billion per year.
Scientists and the Federal Building Minister agree that there must also be more tax advantages for investments in housing.
According to estimates by the Institute for Employment Research, it can be assumed that 55 percent of refugees in Germany will be able to work in the long term.

However, the refugees in Germany are not systematically asked about their qualifications in order to help them get started, criticises Claudia Walter, Project Manager for Integration and Education at the Bertelsmann Foundation.
For the integration of refugees, however, it is crucial whether they find work in Germany.
According to migration researcher Dietrich Thränhardt, work is the key to social contacts, to appreciation in the host society, but also to the self-esteem of immigrants.
According to Thränhardt, there has been a political change in Germany: from banning refugees from working to recognising work.

While asylum seekers were previously banned from working for up to five years, this was reduced to three months in November 2014, as was the Residenzpflicht, which restricts asylum seekers to one place of residence.
In society, the majority view has prevailed - partly because of the shortage of skilled workers - that refugees should be given quicker access to the labour market.
A major obstacle to access to the labour market is a lack of knowledge of German.
To date, there is not yet a sufficient supply of general and vocational language courses.
Research also shows that jobs are most often mediated through face-to-face contact.
According to Thränhardt, the development of networks is therefore the best way to integrate work.

The Berlin school administration has found that only a few refugee parents send their children to daycare, an estimated ten to 15 percent: "For uprooted parents, it is very important to keep the family together," says Ilja Koschembar, spokesman for youth and family in the Berlin Senate Administration.
In order to convince the family of the advantages of the kindergarten, the administration distributes leaflets in different languages.

If the need for kindergarten teachers were to increase sharply due to the large number of refugees, the Berlin Senate would try to increase training capacities - for example, by allowing more technical schools.
In the countries, pupils without knowledge of German are prepared for lessons in welcome classes.

The German Student Union estimates that about 20 percent of refugees want to study in Germany.

In principle, no federal state prohibits asylum seekers or those who are tolerated from studying - the only exception so far has been Berlin, but Interior Senator Frank Henkel (CDU) has now abandoned his position.
Access to higher education could be made easier for would-be refugees.
Refugees with a residence permit or tolerance no longer receive benefits under the Asylum Seeker Benefit Act when they begin their studies.
In principle, the latter do not receive a Bafög, as they do not fall under the category of persons entitled to a Bafög.
Until now, tolerated refugees had to have lived in Germany for four years in order to be eligible for Bafög; from 1 January 2016, this period will be reduced to 15 months.
Steffen Krach, Berlin's State Secretary for Science, and the German Student Union are calling for this funding gap to be closed as well.
Students should get Bafög immediately.
Islam will play a more important role in the future, because many refugees are Muslims, and for many, religion is an important part of their identity.
The state should successively grant Islam the same rights as the churches have, and develop the existing state-church law into a new state-religion relationship.
It would also be important to establish an Islamic welfare association that would take professional care of the new arrivals.
Rights also include obligations.
Thus, the representatives of Islam must agree on clear interlocutors and be prepared to cooperate with the state in many areas and to grant it certain possibilities of control.
This includes a willingness to take bold action against religious fundamentalism.
The chairman of the Central Council of Muslims, Aiman Mazyek, expressed concern on Thursday that religious conflicts could also be brought to Germany.
Those who wanted to carry out such conflicts in Germany "immediately forfeited their right to stay here, in Germany," he told Bayerischer Rundfunk.
He suggested translating the Basic Law into Arabic.
Integration will be an issue for society as a whole much more than it is today.
This means that the majority society will also have to change, and the reduction of discrimination and racism will become more urgent.
As a result of European decisions, Germany has had an Anti-Discrimination Agency and a General Gender Equality Act for almost a decade.
But it learns very slowly, as the NSU murder series showed, in which police and authorities systematically ignored the racist motive.

Equal opportunities for all: What migrant organisations and the interest groups of non-white Germans have been demanding for a long time, and what international agreements such as the Convention on Anti-Racism oblige Germany to do, must become a reality in the coming years if the country is to remain peaceful and its new citizens are to make use of their opportunities - for the benefit of all.

Xi urges wider opening of economy to world
The economy needs to open up more broadly to the outside world to promote growth, President Xi Jinping told a group tasked with steering reform on Tuesday.

China should work to attract foreign investment and know-how and improve business start-up strategies, he said in a speech at the 16th meeting of the Central Leadership Group for Deepening Comprehensive Reform.
Promoting start-ups and pushing ahead with reforms will bring new impetus and vitality and provide new space for economic growth, Xi said.

The leadership group has adopted a number of directives, including a negative list to regulate market access, relaxation of border control policies, encouragement of SOE to raise private capital, and overhaul of the resident registration system.
According to the statement, a negative list will be drawn up identifying sectors and companies that are not eligible for investment.
The system is gradually being tested and improved by test programs.
The initiative is important because it gives the market a greater role in allocating resources, ensures a rule of law business environment and makes the market more open, the statement said.
The government will also relax controls on the powers given to businesses and ensure that companies decide how they conduct their business.
The statement also said that China will allow border areas to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to promote regional growth.
A bid to open up state-controlled sectors will open up more areas to private investment.
The government will not change its policy on foreign investment and will protect the legitimate interests of leveraged companies and provide better services to them, the statement said.
It will also make it easier for foreigners to apply for a permanent residence permit or green card by streamlining requirements and facilitating the application process.

EU to double mercury limit in predatory fish
The European Commission wants to double the limit values for mercury in large predatory fish, thereby requiring consumers to take a significantly higher dose of the nerve agent.

The consumer organisation Foodwatch, which has received a working paper from the EU, strongly criticised the plans: "The risks and side effects of misguided industrial and environmental policies are being passed on to pregnant women and young children with full force," explained Matthias Wolfschmidt of Foodwatch.

According to Wolfschmidt, the limit values for the nerve agent for large fish at the end of the food chain, such as sharks or swordfish, are to be raised from one to two milligrams of mercury per kilogram of fish for "economic reasons."
However, large predatory fish are already so heavily contaminated with mercury that around 50 per cent of catches may not be sold on the basis of the still valid limit values.
After doubling the limit values, only 14.5 percent would be unsaleable.
In exchange for this relaxation, the EU wants to tighten the limit values for other fish from the current 0.5 milligrams to 0.1 milligrams of mercury per kilogram, according to Foodwatch.
However, Foodwatch described this as a "trick" because smaller peacefish, such as carp, are usually so low that they already meet the planned maximum levels.
The reduction in small fish is therefore "a perfidious diversionary manoeuvre that alone helps the economy," Wolfschmidt explained.
Mercury is a heavy metal that is highly toxic to humans and accumulates strongly through the food chain, particularly in predatory fish.
The Federal Government therefore warns that "even small amounts can cause damage to the nervous system, especially in unborn babies."
However, the Federal Ministry for the Environment states on its homepage that a "health hazard to the general population" is not to be expected with regard to the current maximum values.
Mercury enters the environment mainly through coal combustion.

German coal-fired power plants emit more than six tons of mercury a year, two-thirds of the total amount emitted in Germany, according to a written statement from the Federal Ministry for the Environment to Greens member of the Bundestag Annalena Baerbock.
The concentration of mercury in fish, for example in the Elbe, Rhine and Danube, was "permanently and comprehensively exceeded," Der Spiegel had quoted from the paper in March.
Last year, Europe-wide warnings about mercury in fish were already among the most frequently reported health risks in the EU's RASFF alert system.
Foodwatch calls on consumers to protest against EU plans at: www.mercury-aktion.foodwatch.de
